6u3tLcetouk1RtqpHsdVeg.text: My boyfriend and I came here for dinner on a Saturday night.  There was no wait for a party of 2, but any group larger than 2 waited at least half an hour to get a table.  We got the Himalayan Spiced Tea in a little pot to share, it was delicious!  The food was very good, lots of flavor and decent sized portions.  My only negative is that the service was extremely slow.  This is a nice little place to bring a date or a friend, not too fancy but has a nice atmosphere.

j7CB3nKvWeU0FqkRUndi9g.text: In love with the fried tofu. This place has been consistently great for many years. Worth going to Oakland for, and that says a lot.

7oqAS34_VmJMx5XWmQivrQ.text: It was good. My Thai friends liked it so I guess it's close to authentic.

e1wNzkCfS4qbCjRnPrinLA.text: I ordered the Pad Thai. The dish was good, I especially liked the fresh ingredients. I personally like Pad Thai with wider rice noodles. Also we ordered the chicken satay skewers with peanut sauce, which was really good. For the portions however, the price is a little high.

dQgXEHiJOKCEvYoKqkDV7A.text: Nice hidden gem close to UPMC Presbyterian and Pitt.

Ttnw61F5JvXnBceNV1vbfw.text: The food here is incredible. The prices are very reasonable at around ~$10 per entree. This is the best place to have tea in Pittsburgh. I'm amending my old review because I think I gave the owner too much slack because while she makes me nervous, the food comes out extremely quickly and the waitstaff are friendly and helpful. I genuinely think this is one of the best restaurants in Pittsburgh, I went here recently after a Spice Island drought and fell in love again.   I had the Eggplant and Shrimp dish, it was savory and delicious. I cannot recall having a better meal in the past year. The dishes are on the level of E2, Park Bruge, and Eleven. I'm going back here ASAP, and can't wait to try their new drink menu. Here's a hint though: You can still bring your own wine, the waiter told me they were keeping the tradition alive. There's a $10 corking charge per bottle, a bit pricey, but what can you do.

EfdPVl9xqthUm-VKaBn07w.text: Love all the food at Spice Island Tea House, I love the noodles and the curries. The noodles have really big portions and it makes for good leftovers! Little gem in the middle of Oakland. Definitely the best place for sit down food in Oakland.

ym8ezpBcLLxCcoXTCXK9zA.text: It was my second time here for lunch and I had the Singapore rice noodles - includes beef, chicken and shrimp. I was impressed there shrimp serving was pretty decent. This is a good dish but be sure to ask for chilli oil if you like spicy food like i do. You can add this to your taste at the table. This is a popular lunch spot for Pitt students and employees so it can get busy. Probably because they have many dishes for the $9.50 lunch menu. Be prepared to wait if its lunch time. They don't take reservations.

EcHPw59E-4gGdqqqHbjIlg.text: Good americanized Thai food that will satisfy your cravings. Probably my favorite restaurant in the Oakland/Pitt campus area. Lunch specials are quite awesome.

ISDBXBMpiKeeiWECGILH1w.text: The best-kept secret in the Oakland area. My husband took me here and I say the decor. Mismatched chairs and tables. Small space that seems the decor came from the goodwill since none of it matches. Who cares????? The food is amazing. The Pad Thai may be the best I've ever had. It's not much to look at but the food is fantastic and the wait staff is very good as well. Recommend if in the Oakland area.

U9D7C_RfGLNAYYtNTpAlBQ.text: This place is (literally) hidden because of the curtain in front of the windows, but definitely worth going to and it was quite a surprise to find higher quality South Asian food in Oakland. The interior has a lot of character and smells amazing right when you walk in. I got the Java Fried Rice, which was very flavorful and seasoned well. Overall, it was nice to find a new option available in Oakland that can actually compare to Noodlehead and Thai & Noodle Outlet.

L2W7-_4jQeDeusGWRpiRvA.text: You cannot get Pad Thai like this anywhere else. It's simply THE BEST.   We lived in Oakland for years and made Spice Island Tea House a regular visit. My husband and I could split an order of Pad Thai and an order of spring rolls and be comfortably full, spending less than $20 on takeout. We miss Spice Island very much, as we used to eat here about once every 2 weeks.  Should you try it? Yes  Ambience: It's certainly a hard place to find, but that's good because it's truly a hidden gem and will stay that way. On the outside, it looks terrible and hardly even has a legible sign to mark the front door. On the inside, its ambiance is quaint with low-lighting and refurbished antique-like deco that's sure to amuse and delight. They have a vibe all their own, and I'm having a hard time putting it into words.  To be honest, Spice Island was where my husband and I went on our first date. He introduced me to this place and it is now once of our must-visits when visiting Pittsburgh.   Service: Great! It gets busy, but the food generally always comes out very quickly.   Location: Convenient location for anyone living in Oakland (we were on Dawson Street), as this area of the city is very walkable. Perfect for students at Pitt too!   3 Key Tips: 1) Try their teas - they are incredible!  2) Pad Thai. I get it without spice and the taste/texture/temperature is perfecto, but you can have them add spice if you want it!  3) Dishes are large, enough for splitting if you order an appetizer with it!   Recommended Dish: Pad Thai for sure. I also like the Mango Chicken.

DmdRPdcoAUwX2U6tUJkfOg.text: I've had Spice Island Tea House on my radar for months now and finally made it there this past weekend with a friend. It is right next to the pizza place he frequented in college, so we had no trouble finding it even though the sign is a bit faded. We walked in and were immediately greeted and seated by a hostess/server. It wasn't crowded when we arrived (maybe four of the twenty tables were full) but by the time we left the amount of guests had doubled. The decor is adorable, especially the string lights and plants. The place has a clean but worn and comfortable vibe....it's been there since 1995, and it feels like that in a good way.   We took a few minutes to peruse the menus and saw they serve alcohol! Asian food and a nice beer happens to be a favorite combination of mine. Their cocktails look great as well. I'll certainly be back to try the Bangkok mule. For food I went with the Pad Thai, and he had the Thai Red Chili wok fry with chicken. Our food arrived within twenty minutes or so, and we immediately began eating.   I can see why people rave about the Pad Thai here. It's incredibly rich with lots of egg and peanut and a delicious sauce that stands up to the accompaniments very well. I'll get it again but with more spice next time. I didn't specify a spice level when ordering (the waitress never asked and I totally forgot to be honest) so I assume what I received was the mild spice level. I requested Sriracha, which I was generous with, and that added a little kick. My friend loved his wok fry and said it was plenty spicy for him. It looked very flavorful, with a deep red sauce and lots of chilies. The portions of both dishes were quite large for the quality of food we received. I feel like sometimes the nicer Thai-style places give you a bit less for your money. We left full and satisfied with plans to come back very soon!

KrqEbOuOQaYPpG9rpWM__Q.text: This is a nice quaint tea house with a good selection of teas to warm you up on a cold day.  These are brewed and served in ceramic teapots.  They also have an interesting menu of curries, brick oven baked breads and fritters for example.  A shrimp fritter appetizer was shared with my date and we both found it delicious.    Reversing roles in the famous Jack Spratt nursery rhyme I enjoyed the flatter, oilier man bread and she the puffier paratha. Based on a Yelp recommendation, she ordered the Burmese pork curry and enjoyed it but not enough to have the take home as a meal the next day.    I have a passion for green curry and took the waitress's suggestion for a large shrimp green curry.  I enjoyed the dish and the leftovers the next day.   (Waste not want not).      I recommend Spice Island Tea House as a pleasant restaurant.  It is not highest among many options for Eastern food but is enjoyable.  Parking can be tricky in this section of Oakland, so be aware.

K3WfDMSG9hc23TTrzaWTsA.text: Hole in the wall, great find!  On the outside I'd never think of trying this place out,  BUT it's very quaint and cute inside and the food is amazing!!  Chicken curry with coconut rice is the bomb!

yMYkSisF_dw5ny2L1ocetg.text: Pretty good, but I think my noodle dish was just regular spaghetti? Definitely want to try again

hXeqGA3SZPgc2oYQmD809w.text: We used to love this place but our recent visit left us disappointed. It was a Friday night and they were completely dead. All of the staff was sitting at a table drinking tea and hanging out. We ordered a really good blended tea and appetizers my boyfriend got the fish cakes said they were decent I got the ginger salad which I love. I ordered the basil fried rice which had zero flavor and not hint of basil. I doused it in the chili oil to get it down. My boyfriend got their "specialty shrimp" which were a few large shrimp in a weird thick sauce that reminded me of Swedish meatballs . Gross.  Last time we ate here we loved our meal. Most likely won't be going back.

cKIpqNN3IVIJ85kFoYGG5A.text: Finally decided to stop by Spice Island for dinner after all the wonderful reviews I read on here. Maybe I came in expecting too much, but walked out of the restaurant quite disappointed. I mean the food was edible, just not fantastic. Atmosphere was warm and cozy, and service was fast and on point.   I ordered the mango pork. First of all, I just want to say that I don't think the price is worth it for the portion. I paid ~$12 for a small bowl of pork and scoop of coconut rice, with a few strands of vegetables and a tiny slice of naan out of pity. It's not painfully expensive, but still on the pricier side, deserving "$$". The coconut rice was very good, and probably my favorite thing on the plate. The mango pork tasted exactly like curry pork. I couldn't find a hint of mango anywhere. Meat was soft and melted right in my mouth, but the seasoning was just average--a little too salty. All of the friends complained about the quantity and quality of their food as well. The one friend ordered their vegetarian pad thai and ended up with sour tofu in her pad thai. My assumption was the tofu went bad.   Overall the food here is edible, but I will not return due to the price, quantity and quality. I don't think their food is worth $12 because I could get the same thing for half the price at a food cart elsewhere. If you do decide to come here, one suggestion: Make sure you double check their TOFU.

ccyRLFJXpNC_mYm8J7yDqg.text: Food is good as always. This time the portions were very small this time. And as normal the service was horrible!! I walked in with my son.. she was late to greet us despite the place being empty. She asked if I knew what I wanted or did I need a menu? No welcome nothing!! She is just not pleasant. I asked to pack my food and my tea. She attempted to take my cup with her. I said no just pls bring me a to-go cup. She comes back and slams my cup on the table.   Her server number is 0004 she never told me her name so I have no idea!! Just don't understand if you don't like ppl then get the heck out of service industry!!   And wear a bra for heavens sake!!  2nd encounter with her If things do not improve I will not be back!!!

hn8PcLDHsTN_zWaWvibQeQ.text: Bad food bad service. This is not real Burmese food. Very bland. Servers and hosts are aloof. Owner or asian manager also is aloof . So many better options in the area.

vuBkQ1jcfkaK0o7egwpXjg.text: Very bland. below mediocre . Little to no taste, pretty much soaked rice noodles with some store bought sauce. I got pad thai with tofu. Tofu was alright as well, little under cooked so it had that watery texture you feel when you take it out of the packet. Also when I called for take out, they said it would be ready in 5-10 min, so either the quality of work is very low, or they gave me a previous order.

Bp-y6-LiX5CR_UIipTB0pw.text: Great food and price! I had the veggie pad Thai and loved it. The Thai iced tea was fantastic. The service is very good. Quick, polite and efficient. We will definitely be back!!

m0DGZ_-7Zdj63jWThq50pg.text: Stopped by for a pot of tea and some samosas. Almost thought I had missed it because the sign is faded. Walking distance from the hospitals. Quiet with steady business when I was there. I hear the food is really good; I'll come during a meal next time to try some. Server was not overbearing. Good luck finding parking on the street, which is $$$ anyway.  Came back six months later, and I still like the place. Hubby and I arrived early, before the dinner rush, and they agreed to seat the 2 of us because I wanted to order appetizers. Our party of 4 eventually ordered from all parts of the menu, and we were extremely happy with our dishes. Portion sizes vary: the Burmese chicken curry was too small to split, so we got an Indonesian salad, and that was more than we could eat together. The spring rolls were also delicious. Parking is still scarce and $$$.

i8JsbsViYR4JaqAIK5EoAw.text: I ordered the veg monsoon, with a side of coconut rice with the mango black tea, and a gin mule, the tea was perfect the mule was one of the best I've ever had, the veg monsoon is a dish unmatched compared to other local spots dishes as far as I'm concerned. The waitress I had was nice and polite and always made sure that my water cup was filled and even packaged the rest of my mean for me to take it to go. If you come to Pittsburgh and don't know where to go to eat this establishment should be at the top of your list

KUd8olao2fbDEJfhgHM4mg.text: I was just curious about this place and good reviews, but it wasn't good. Curry- it's not Thai curry, without coconut taste and vegetables, just the meat and rice. Place very nice inside, may be I should try another main course, but I don't want do it again.

aIeA1Qvow-K7Un_c7uj1Eg.text: I had the Singapore noodles which tasted pretty authentic to me (not that I've had it in Singapore...). Maybe a little greasy but that's like all the Asian food I've had in Pittsburgh. Especially when I was finishing it up, i realized half of the noodles were literally soaked in oil. Also the waitress kept rushing us on everything (I.e. ordering food, getting a box, getting the check etc.) which felt a bit unpleasant. We were there at 6pm so it wasn't even close to their time of closing.

Q28fPrk5VZWw60TdxpXpXQ.text: Oakland's hidden gem. A perfect date location for friends and lovers alike. Definitely try the Malasian saute. :)

qZDhBSOCyOYdKbEatWLQdA.text: Amazing place. Ambience not too good but the food covers for it. Try the Java Fried Rice it is out of this world. Mango chicken was good too. If you like spicy food Java fried rice is the best.

NgrYHamUzW8O3iskPdtuWA.text: Pan-Asian food.  Loose leaf tea and good vegetarian options.  Restaurant is in-line with Pittsburgh's tradition of fine eating establishments that look like pawn shops on the outside.  Seating can be tight during peak hours, but this is because it is the best place to dine in Oakland.

UynS4uHhSpNguECZKQqvAA.text: Loved this place!! We were in town checking out the University of Pittsburgh for our daughter. My husband found this place on-line and I was a little skeptical. I had my heart set on something upscale, just because we don't usually eat at upscale restaurants unless we are on the road. But I am so glad he talked me into it! The atmosphere was so cool and the food was wonderful! I had the Lemongrass beef which was so flavorful and simply delicious. My husband had the Mohinga Of Burma which he said was amazingly tasty. Our daughters had Tofu salad dishes and they both cleaned their plates--unusual for them. My husband and I also enjoyed the cocktails and the girls liked the choice of teas. What a great value too. We would definitely come back. I wish I could pick this place up and move it to Chicago!

RlcBbMH0UMHtqdFOkZprxQ.text: Finally got to go there and I will definitely go back! I had the beef rendang and my friend had the pad thai. The rendang is amazing! The best part of my dish was the paratha (the flat bread) that came as a side. The beef was tender and the dish had layers of flavor. The coconut rice side was great too. My friend loved his pad thai so much, he finished the big plate of food and got some carry-out for his lady. The service is solid, very attentive and the servers know the food.

p7gBUgvgLKAJbIEScaM4XQ.text: Everything they do is very good. Tea selection is amazing and one of the reason I keep coming back.  Interior is much more pleasant then the exterior, so it is worth braving the sketchy looking outside.  Seating can be a toss-up. I have had time when I can sit right down for dinner and other times when I have to wait a long time. If you have a party over 4 you are much more likely to be waiting for a while.

loRp0QUAUG8Az6Awm0VsBw.text: If you told me they put drugs in their food I'd believe you because it's that damn good. You get chicken and shrimp in the java fried rice and pad thai for under $10, a pot of tea for like $3 for a table, I mean you just can't beat it.  The flavor is much better than other restaurant's in other parts of town for half the price. I'm not knocking the others, it's just that spice Island takes Thai food and does their own thing and it is amazing.

3OCqp1Bo7UoiL_dhnKMqBQ.text: I've had some of the best loose leaf tea here...   I've had mixed luck with the food -- one dinner was excellent whereas a lunch seemed too salty. Definitely better to eat here rather than take out as I think the take-out suffers. For what it's worth, they do have beer and wine. I'm not super excited about this place, but I would probably go back if others wanted to go (i.e. I doubt if I would choose it myself again).

MoODL-hvxg2VlkOxSSvKAQ.text: This is one of Oakland and Pittsburgh's best kept secrets. Can be difficult to find with a dull sign and curtains over the door but the atmosphere inside is warm and comfortable. They have both cold and hot tea of the day for $1. Also a nice wine and beer selection. The food is always outstanding. We order the pad thai at least once per week. The portions are large and usually enough for 2 meals. I've tried pad thai at every other restaurant in Pittsburgh and elsewhere and Spice Island is hands down our favorite!

B3IQYXZBEiwnqZF--ZHalQ.text: Good food comes from a cardboard menu.  I love the cardboard menu's here.  The menus are in these great cardboard holders that are accented with duct tape and they are just great.  Good food, reasonably priced.   I had the ruby chicken - it was delicious.  They now have serve alcohol - last time I was here it was BYOB.  I really appreciate that they serve ice cream from their neighbor and one of the most amazing ice cream shops - Dave and Andy's which is located just a block away.

Xn7jVBh4VMO1sPPJqkkptw.text: Although the facade makes this place seem less then stellar from the outside, once you actually go inside, it is rather good.  The environment was comfortable and the service was really impressive.  Most importantly, the food was tasty too.  A nice plus is that the portions are of a perfect size.

lQOO246cSPznJLKSZRntcg.text: So I've been wanting to writing a review for this place for a long time. This is a great spot for lunch if you're in the area. The outside is not much to look at but when you walk inside you can see it's a nice little cafe. Menu is not big but they've got something for everyone. Love the tea variety they got here and price is reasonable. Liked there Burmese chicken, Mango pork, Thai beef salad, and fried rice with Chinese sausage. Portions are not super big but just right for me. Good for casual date or girls hang out.

hc_0Y0i1jgQoFFVl34ouwg.text: Food is excellent and the dimly lit, swanky atmosphere makes me feel so much cooler than I am.  I also love being in a place where you can mingle with other urbanites, bouncing ideas off each other and enjoying good conversation.  Ginger Peanut Salad is my favorite dish.  I wish all those people who are bitching about large portions would get a life before they ruin it for me.  The service would be the only reason I cannot give 5 stars.  It's ok.  Not great.  When they get busy, stuff gets forgotten about and it is not unusual to have to flag someone down.  Also, I wish it was open later.  I seem to like it so much more when I go there later on, and given the place closes at 9, I dont go there as much as I would like to, because I dont want to be "that guy"

NXBRPgDbfMgFBWZTl06K-w.text: Went there the other night for dinner. It looked kind of dumpy from the outside (lots of garbage), but the interior was clean and cozy. We had two dishes that were super tasty, Popiah rolls and chicken sate skewers.  The Popiah roll, kind of like a "cold spring roll", was delicious - especially when dipped into the sweet soy sauce. The chicken sate skewers were juicy and could be eaten with or without dipping into peanut sauce. If you're not a big eater, the sides that came with the skewers could be a bit daunting - we saw quite a few patrons leaving with doggy bags.  The only bad thing to say about the food was that the vatayna rice was bland and dry (mixed with peanut sauce, it was nice. Next time, I would keep the sweet soy sauce from the appetizer to use on the rice).  Would definitely go again!

qvvaYgdHuihqYAJThqHB-Q.text: Not bad for my first Thai food experience! Comfortable place. May try other dishes later~

9i9YWjM7N74T_S_oYSKAOA.text: This is an amazing place.  You may initially be put off by the run down storefront look or how dark it is inside, but if you are hungry this is the place to go.   I've had most of the dishes on the menu; it was my regular lunch place when I worked nearby.   They all are excellent and I can't wait to go visit it again.  Try the Rangoon Night Market Noodle. It is outrageous.

iBb3tCKPaTy74onTzZq5Vg.text: After eating here several times over years I rate this a solid SE Asian option for Pittsburgh. The real casual as opposed to faux casual atmosphere and friendly, helpful staff keep the rating up to a solid 4 stars.  The food is tasty and greasy and reasonably priced with large portions. My favorite is the spicy noodles listed after the Pad Thai on the menu. It has a slightly more Chinese brown sauce flavor but I like the added spice. The vegetables vary and the rice noodles are wider than Pad Thai. I wish the sauce was a bit lighter but I imagine that doesn't bother the locals.   The hot and iced teas of the day are always fun to try.

r4ix814oUQc0KS-89lXuEA.text: I hardly need to add to the long list of good reviews, so I'll keep this short.  Positives:  As a soon-to-be Pitt employee, I'm awfully glad that this place is just around the corner in Oakland.  Good menu of (I think) Thai and Burmese dishes.  Fantastic tea menu with a nice group-couch area up front seemingly for those who just want tea and conversation.  Nice art and furniture.  Well organized menu.  Lots of healthy items, and just about anything can be made vegetarian if that's your thing.  Very affordable; one person could easily do a filling lunch for ~$10 with a drink.  And prompt service with a smile.  Negatives:  Minor things, really.  The menu is a tad long, though admittedly, there are some interesting dishes that you don't normally see in a SE Asian restaurant.  The lighting is great if there's some sun in the sky, but was a bit too dim on a cloudy 2/10/2010.  My dish--the Garden Veggies with Sweet Ginger Sauce and tofu--tasted great, but was way too saucy.  More veggies, less sauce, would have made it perfect.  Lastly, it's unfortunately got a very unappealing facade, but don't judge this place by the cover.  I plan to return and to recommend it highly to others.

Oe1DjRsXAU-y67ZdWTU9Mg.text: I have both eaten in and taken out with a positive experience.   From walking by, it doesn't look like the greatest place, but they have an interesting menu with different asian/asian fusion dishes so there's a little bit for everyone from the exotic to the simple.  The Malaysian Sate, which I had with beef, was delicious and came in a more than adequately sized portion. The Pad Thai is also a delicious meal. All of the appetizers and other dishes I tried were more than satisfactory.   For a student on a budget, this place is both delicious and relatively inexpensive. I would recommend it to anyone who likes interesting tastes of Asia.

dBDEiNoQVzZMNcGSf1gzLw.text: This restaurant, hidden in the side streets off the popular Forbes avenue,  is a lovely Eastern European blend of foods, with a large (cardboard!) menu displaying a large variety of dishes, with many vegetarian options, and almost everything with tofu-substitutes. The tea bar is extensive, with a wide variety of blends beyond your everyday greens, blacks, and herbals; the waitress serves teas stewing in the pot with a time estimate on when the tea will be perfectly brewed and delicious. The food was fast, good, and very hearty, with enough leftovers to serve me for dinner as well, and kind and helpful waitresses came and checked on me numerous times during my meal, despite almost all the other tables being full. All in all, an excellent experience, and I give it two thumbs up.

0LJ61whDExoqRRMvgkAY6w.text: I decided to go to this restaurant after reading quite a few good reviews. We were seated promptly and got water and orders placed quickly. I ordered the mango pork, and when the food arrived at the table I sensed something was wrong. My food looked and tasted EXACTLY like beef rendang. I've had beef rendang hundreds of times starting in my infancy, it's a staple food in my life, and this was it. It had small chunks of potatoes in it, and a coconut milk taste like mentioned in the menu. Clearly not mango pork.   I asked the waitress if my food was the beef rendang or the mango pork, and she absolutely insisted it was the mango pork. I mentioned that there was no "pickled mango" like mentioned in the menu (in fact, no mango taste at all) and she just said the beef rendang was green-tinged, there was no actual mango in the mango pork, and I definitely had the mango pork. She did not address my concerns about the difference in ingredients/menu description at all. Also, beef rendang is never green, so I don't know what they would be serving as beef rendang. I highly suspect they just didn't want to admit their mistake and therefore remake my food.  The food was actually pretty good, which is a pity because the whole experience made me not want to go back. I love southeast Asian cuisine because it reminds me of home, but I specifically didn't order the beef rendang because I wanted to try something different. The rendang was decent but just flat-out not what I ordered. I'd have been fine if they just messed up my order, because I know mix-ups happen, but the wait staff seemed unwilling to do anything about it besides just insisting my food was something it wasn't.

BwuA517WHoHaFofeF1DWmg.text: I was visiting Carnegie Mellon the day after and I stopped to have dinner here. The restaurant had fabulous good and I really really enjoyed the staff. Thanks for some great food!!!!

NC3Yw_NKy1DBLZ3ymkMIJQ.text: This is a favorite stop when friends come to town. The environment is unique. The food is delicious. I love the Thai Tea and was only disappointed with a noodle dish that lacked flavor due to my friend that can't handle its heat (we asked for it mild). I typically enjoy a walk around town afterwards. This place comes highly recommended!

vzYu44vjqT2E8cDNWfdqQg.text: This was my favorite restaurant when I was in college at CMU. It was sort of my introduction to hip, local spots with a focus on food and it was definitely the first Southeast Asian I had experienced.  I've returned many times throughout my visits back to Pittsburgh. And I'm not sure if my tastebuds have changed or they've started to sell out (they do focus on some cheesy cocktails now when it used to be BYOB), but it wasn't quite the same.  It was so quiet on a Saturday night at 8pm. We were seriously one of only two tables in the entire place. I realized it might be because school is out for summer. But it was a bit disconcerting.  I ordered the same thing I've gotten here for 10 years - the Shan Hin Lay Pork. I remember the pot roast texture and tenderness of the pork with a sweet brown sauce and great coconut rice. Well, this time around I noticed the meat was rather fatty and that sauce was pretty bland.   I will say the other dishes were all pretty good. I do remember their great spring rolls. The pad thai had a tangy sweetness that you don't always find in Thai restaurants. And the Penang Curry was bright and spicy.  I think it might be time for me to move on. If I do come back here, it will probably be for nostalgia sake and I may have to retire my regular dish and try something with a bit more oomph. But then again, who am I kidding? I'm a creature of habit and I only come to Pittsburgh once in a blue moon. It might be nice to act like I'm in college again. By eating bland, fatty pork.  -eatthisny

NI7hx3l44zFEf9Iz6jXD9A.text: My second visit last night - the atmosphere is really nice inside (on the outside, it seems shady). We got the crabmeat spring rolls, deep-fried hard boiled egg with tomato chilli sambal, and the ever-famous pad thai.   The crabmeat spring rolls were okay (there were two). But the deep-fried hard boiled egg (2 eggs actually) with tomato chilli sambal was DELICIOUS! Everything about that dish makes me want to eat it again and again.  The ever-famous pad thai was very good too. They don't dump a lot peanuts on top like other restaurants do. The portion size is really big too, I even got some left-overs for today!

Rfl7vsb-lKy2StQ87IoAEQ.text: Love Love Love the mango pork.  You'd never think to try it walking by on the street, but it's an amazing find.

bwndzJJCRfTfDLvgxCBa0w.text: I absolutely love pad thai in general- and HATED it here.  I tried to make it better by mixing in some spicy sauce, but that didn't work at all.  My boyfriend a had a curry dish that he enjoyed.  I'd be willing to go back and update my rating if my new dish was tastier and I definitely wouldn't order the pad thai.

I4RceZyRTjvLeJpAuQxgYQ.text: I searched for restaurants near Kinko's, because I had to go make some copies. It turns out Atwood St is packed with them. I decided to try these guys because I was looking for something a little wacky, and also a little Asian. ;)  I was in the mood for some sort of tasty salad, and the first one listed on the menu was the Gado! Gado! (yes, that's the way it was written on the menu). The rest of the menu was pretty extensive with lots of different pan-Asian and Southeast Asian-ish dishes.  The salad was good, a mix of poached cauliflower, broccoli, and green beans with raw bean sprouts and cucumbers. The whole thing was covered with a sweet peanut sauce. It was quite nice, although the peanut sauce became a little too much towards the bottom of the salad (it was SOAKED). The portion was quite large, definitely enough to be my full dinner with a side of white rice.  I also ordered the "Ice Tea of the Day" which was Jasmine today. It was good. Not really very special, except that ordering ice tea at any other place gets you Lipton's "finest," ya dig.  I would definitely go there again to try some other stuff on the menu. It also looked like a nice place to bring a date or meet friends. The wait staff when I was there was a pair of young and friendly women who seemed eager to make the guests' experiences pleasant.  My whole meal (the three things listed above) was about $9.50.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Gado! Gado! salad with a side of white rice and a Jasmine iced tea.

N-SsIeU7Om1XU3kkL6Zonw.text: This was a great find walking down Atwood St.!  We walked inside and the ambience was perfect, and it turned out to be happy hour.  Luckily there's a nice beer list here to accompany the delicious Asian cuisine!  The menu is full of soo many dishes that are atypical for the standard Asian restaurant menus.  It took almost 15 minutes just to figure out what to order, many of the dishes I'd never seen before sounded quite appealing.  *Go here if you want a break from the typical Asian food and want to explore things you've never tasted*  I went with a Malaysian dish, slow-marinated beef with spices and coconut milk (can't remember the name - but it's on the "off the beaten path" menu under "Malaysia").  It was FANTASTIC!  The beef was so tender that I could poke it apart with my chopsticks with no knife, and the flavor was phenomenal.  Notice: I said "poke" it apart with chopsticks... they don't automatically give you chopsticks here for some reason, and the food doesn't always come out ready to be eaten with chopsticks.  That undermines the authenticity a little too much for me, hence the 4 stars.

X3NaR6EOXRYESLDZABiNiQ.text: I very much enjoyed my dinner there a few days ago. The pork mango was very tasty! It's to my knowledge the best price/quality ratio of Oakland (entrees are around $11-13). The room is friendly and warm, although there is not much space between tables. The waiters were very helpful. Many Pitt undergrads, which you may, or may not, like...

um6J-ppCClke3VP7mXedBw.text: This is another one of the collection of small restaurants around Oakland that are good.  The restaurant serves Indochinese cuisine with lots of noodle dishes. The food is good and priced very well making it an enjoyable dining experience.  We were here multiple times while we went to CMU and would go again.

EnUT8T7RcDlk9iP0WP1o-w.text: I love spice island. The mango chicken is awesome. I never have a bad experience here.

hhuTUVLGGmot3umvHlpewQ.text: Excellent place for lunch; good vegetarian options. Delightful server. Loved the apricot tea. We'll be back!

sXlAcrmo8uBFnOkg8DtPmA.text: I love their noodle dishes! It looks like a hole in the wall from the outside but don't be afraid to venture in. It has a much nicer appearance inside and you will find yourself craving their noodles at random moments.

9BG7JslhHb_f2iUtx5AE3w.text: Great food! This is one of the few places where I like pretty much everything. If I stop by for lunch, I usually order a curry. Their curries taste slow-cooked and home-cooked, something you can find in only a few places. This is also one of the few places where you can frequently find college students in flip flops and businessmen in suits sitting at adjacent tables. This place gets pretty loud during lunchtime, so you'll have to raise your voice to have a conversations..

Q669c6VJgxmlxye3OoGAlg.text: The food here is very fresh and very thai.  I really enjoyed the red curry with chicken -you need to try!  Ive eaten Thai at other places in Pittsburgh (and there are really no good asian restaurants in pittsburgh anyway), and this is THE place for Thai.

zAjzNnbzttRFYfVDbQRvmQ.text: Excellent food. Good beer selection. Seating is cramped especially for us larger guys.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Green curry

O7QRHQ74yvYuEH3zMDZniw.text: Delicious. I love the atmosphere her, the waitstaff is friendly, and it's excellent Southeast Asian food.  Ask the server for suggestions - I've been happy with everything suggested to me.

EraUL2-rpp2GEOaPISNVXw.text: among the best thai i've ever had.  fantastic environment.  quaint.  thai tea is great.  pad thai is good, but not the best i've had.  i haven't tried any yet, but it appears they have some good beer as well.  i plan on returning whenever possible.

dOZ3nsBJtVf32n3Ywc7MWA.text: Overall, this place is a standard and solid Thai restaurant.  I came here with my friend, upon her suggestion, and I can see why this was on the top of her recommendations. I tried the Pad Thai and they gave me a good portion. The food itself was good, but a bit too sweet for my liking. But that's honestly me being picky.  The atmosphere is very peace-inducing. And the service is pretty friendly.  I would come here again, as the location is fairly close to Pitt campus ... but I wouldn't say this is the best Thai restaurant I've ever visited, although it is the closest to me.

7LdtvBpnJT9wL4PqkvoOnA.text: Step in off the street, and you may feel as though you've been transported to another land. Spice Island Tea House is like a spice trader's cozy port-town shop. A mix of elegant decor and lush plants lends to the whimsical feel of the place.  For the most part, the food is prepared in straight-forward ways that let the spices do the talking; and my, do they talk! Eloquently, cleverly... Every meal I've ever had here has impressed me with the complexity of the spice combination. From curries to noodle dishes, on every plate it's the masterful use of spices that steals the show!  A note to tea lovers: This place is not to be missed. The selection of quality teas should satisfy even the most discerning tea critic. My personal lunch recommendation would have to be the Rangoon Night Market Noodle dish. The marriage of spices in this meal perfectly showcase the mastery that is inherent in the Spice Island kitchen.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Inside is like a cozy spice trader&#39;s shop... Lovely plants and elegant decor, paired with dim lighting, lend to an enchanting effect.

X6Kz_h0qvBYn5gvJTC2HXw.text: My mom and I recently decided to try Spice Island again after not having been for many years. We used to go there all the time but stopped shortly after they removed my mom's favorite dish from the menu. However on a whim we decided to go again. The atmosphere of the restaurant is warm, dim litted, and peaceful, however, we were getting takeout so we didn't stay in the restaurant for long. I ordered Singapore Char Kway Teow without shrimp. My mom's order was more special. After describing the dish that she hasn't been able to get for almost a decade, the hostess went back to the kitchen to see if it could be recreated. My mom began to cry when she came back saying that yes, they could make it. For those wondering it is a ground chicken dish with mint, rice, and jalepeno. When we received our food and got home we found that the food was as good as we'd remembered except that my mom had to add jalepeno to the chicken. My noodles were delicious and they brought back strong memories of eating them before. I think we were both feeling nostalgic that night and to me that's how good food should make you feel.

yg_A5dcj02EuXwy0p3-2kg.text: I've been here multiple times already and the food is really yummy! I've tried their Java Fried Rice, Pad Thai, and Singaporean Rice Noodle - which are all delicious! The best part is that they all come with combination of proteins (chicken, beef, and shrimp) - so no need to choose between any of them! They're really flexible with making the dish milder or spicier so don't be afraid to ask the waiter for a customized order.  I've had really positive experiences here. The waiters are usually very friendly and cooperative - and the food comes out relatively fast. This place can get busy during popular dinner hour so expect to wait a bit sometimes - especially with larger groups.   Definitely would recommend this restaurant! Can be a bit "pricey"! Dishes are about $12 each.   Aside: If you don't like "sweet" pad thai, then I would not recommend it from Spice Island. I personally am not a big fan of the sweet flavor.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Java Fried Rice + Singaporean Rice Noodle
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Java Fried Rice

ZdTAGfb7V1PkDMEEEUgF9A.text: Cute and small place with excellent Thai food that hits the spot. I ordered the Pad Thai w/ chicken it was amazing! I also ordered the vegetarian spring roll that was so light and crispy. Simply delightful! And the portion size was great for the price. My friends enjoyed their meal as well. One friend raved about her Java Rice.  I don't get a chance to peruse to Oakland often, but when I do...I will be sure to stop here if I have a taste for some delicious Pad Thai!

yjLm-ceWFCZ4SOfGcy4HtQ.text: Incredibly good. South Asian food is not easy to find here in Pittsburgh and their curry and stewed dishes are awesome. Never had a bad dish here. I was very disappointed that they stopped serving the eggplant and shrimp paste dip though recently.   Oh, and the sell booze! Would be a great date spot I'd imagine but I always go for lunch.

AEPUpB6hyg_MZlc8ulqI2g.text: Java's fried rice tastes good! The restaurant has a stylish decoration. Waitresses were really nice.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Y3PQQceeLfwqrMNZt-noCw.text: Found this little whole in the wall place while I attended college in Pittsburgh. From the outside it doesn't look like there is anything there but don't be fooled there is such a nice restaurant inside. It is Thai food and it is decent. I am giving three stars because there are better Thai places in Pittsburgh and this place lacks a little bit of the kick that i look for in Thai food. Otherwise my friends as well love it and it's not too pricey for a college town and really nice when you want to go somewhere randomly but don't know where. Definitely worth a try and I normally get the red curry and chicken skewers which I have to say are amazing! enjoy!

TCa0V_7coNXH347ASn9dcg.text: I stumbled on this little place on a rainy Monday night. If you're not looking for this place you will walk right by. This place is a gem. To warm up from the cold rain we ordered a large pot of gunmetal green tea. My table ordered the veggie spring rolls and they were delicious! The sauce they came with is really yummy. I ordered the java fried rice and I am  in heaven! It has a sweet taste and the rice is moist without being saucy. The java fried rice has chicken and shrimp and you can adjust the heat to your liking. The portion of rice that you receive is honestly enough to fill two people! The staff is really friendly, and they even offer 5% off your bill if you pay in cash! Great food and discounts, I am so in! I don't live in Pittsburgh, but I will make sure to be back here next visit...

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

1u6Djca8CRBAKLhjMqAAcw.text: The most amazing pad Thai I have ever eaten. The panong curry was also wonderful! Our waitress was a very friendly and helpful and the overall experience was just wonderful! I will definitely be back!

MWkD2dQ3o5jk7L_LdOftUg.text: Great restaurant option in Oakland, PA. servers were attentive and friendly, good was very good and ambiance was charming. We went for a date night and criwd was nice mix of students and older adults. Started with the spring rolls which were light and crispy. My date had Burmese chicken curry and I had satay chicken with peanut sauce. Both were very good and flavorful. Would definitely go back if in the area.

mPy5TRvQRSnprtgSIgLhXQ.text: I haven't been here in awhile. I went there couple days ago after almost two years, and it's still as good as I remember. The menu changed a little bit I tried their Burmese food. Mmmm I'm so glad I did. I went there around 11:45, first day of school for the undergrads but the restaurant isn't too pack. Thankfully we were seated right away and we barely waited for our food. The atmosphere of the restaurant is great. It is such a relaxing place with dim lights and candle. Their menu got good selection of Asian food, many things I tried prior to this review were all on point!  This time both Me and my friend both ordered their Burmese chicken curry with coconut rice. I think I inhaled it, nothing left on my plate. The chicken was sooo tender and the curry was perfect. I definitely will not wait so long again to come back.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken satay
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Burmese chicken curry! So gooood!
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Burmese chicken curry, highly recommend it

AzToUFENcHxW4oHjzwcNXw.text: This is my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh! A small hole-in-the-wall with wonderful food, friendly service, and cozy decor. I took my server's recommendation and ordered the Chiang Mai Noodles - it was delicious!! The dish was cooked perfectly with fresh ingredients, and just a kick of spice! The portion was very large and the price was very reasonable. Can't wait to come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Super cozy interior. &#34;Hole in the wall&#34; perfection

F9-cDoJMJclh4F5hO13hPA.text: If you're tired of the lower quality Asian cuisine nearer central campus, a trip down Atwood to the divey, cozy Spice Island Tea House is a zesty move. With a diverse variety of authentic Thai/Asian Fusion, Spice Island is worth the extra dollar sign. The menu at this unassuming location is exciting, with opportunities to cleanse your pallet with greens in between bursts of exotic flavors from the assorted curries, fried rices, stir-fries, and soups on this menu. Check out the teas, there are some really interesting options available.  If you have dietary restrictions, this place is very accommodating. Dish contents are clearly listed on the menu, and the waiting staff is very knowledgeable about spices and seasonings used in the kitchen. Don't be afraid to ask if you need an accommodating. They were great with helping me!  I got my food to go and was honestly a little disappointed that I could not sit and experience more of this restaurant. Guess I'll have to return sometime soon!

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Panang Style Curry Chicken (comes with white rice)
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Burmese Fried Rice

LYBDVbGsYLmc1VO6voLn5g.text: Recently ate here for the first time in a while and was reminded of how delicious this place is! Menu is easy to navigate, with so many options, and vegan & vegetarian items clearly marked. They offer Malaysian, Singaporean, Burmese, and Indonesian, as well as Thai dishes, so you'll find some pretty authentic dishes I haven't stumbled upon in any other Pittsburgh Thai restaurant. Service is always fast and dishes are always so consistent, flavorful, with large portions so always leftovers to take home. LOVE their fresh Thai rolls, as they're made with Popiah skin which is a very thin crepe like flour rather than the traditional rice papers, very different and so far the only place in Pittsburgh I've found these. Can't wait to try some more menu items. Also offer a very large tea selection.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

9JaOL-tbrosW728bHZF0jA.text: Spice Island is definitely a hidden gem in Oakland. I had never heard of it before and a colleague suggested we all grab lunch there. Little fact this place does offer gluten free options.  I was surprised by its variety of Southeast Asian options on one menu. I personally tried the Burmese pork and coconut rice and added a side salad. The salad was phenomenal and I was taken back by the complexity of flavors within such a simple dish. But the pork was everything! It was absolutely one of the best dishes I've had in a long time. The meat was so tender and full of flavor. The spice of the pork alongside the sweetness of he rice was perfect.  I also sampled the three veggie curry that my colleague had and it was amazing. I do not not travel to Oakland much but when I am there this is a place high on my priority list to visit. This is definitely a must try if you already haven't.

u5yAhrfztN0x8PBNC8hIGA.text: Don't judge a book by it's cover... this is really delicious Thai!! As you approach from the outside you may notice that it looks like a complete dump. However, many of my favorite restaurants do. We had Pad Thai and a spicy noodle/gravy dish that I can't remember the name of (with chicken and vegetables). We also had an appetizer of a flatbread with a meat curry as well as a Thai iced tea. I will say that the meat curry sauce was probably my favorite part of the whole meal. Both of our dishes were pretty great and came out quickly, but not TOO fast... if you know what I mean.  As you may know, the Pad Thai comes with chicken and shrimp. If I were to go back, I would probably ask if I could get all shrimp or maybe vegetables instead. Some of the chicken was kind of... questionable. Maybe just overcooked. But the sauce and noodles were absolutely delicious.  One thing I do want to note is that unlike a lot of other local Thai places, they do serve alcohol. You do have the option to BYO but it's a $10 corking fee.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The Thai Iced Tea
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The ever famous pad thai!! The sauce was great. It comes with chicken and shrimp.

HkuVtTfYiO1ON7tyQA3NMA.text: Came to this restaurant for the first time and it was all i could ask for. The atmosphere was pleasent and good for conversation, the food came quickly and the servers were all very nice. The curry trio was great--always looking for great vegan options.   Definitely worth the trip.

_ZwO6gOOoZfgUGEEzC94fg.text: I love this place! A quaint little tea shop, which sells delicious Asian food. We usually get the thai iced tea, which is good. Our favorites are the Burmese Chicken Curry. We recently tried Thai-style Wok-charred Chili and Garlic Chicken, and it was really delicious.  There are SO many items in the menu , that we have a hard time to decide. Will definitely be back to try the other items.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Newest addition to menu an appetizer with roti &amp; Burmese curry!
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Thai style basil fried rice
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chang Mai noodles! Delicious

jVVieFDBswOq4D0XIOtQhQ.text: The java fried rice is the best fried rice in Pittsburgh hands down; not overpoweringly spicy but still has a good bit of heat, and a nice mixture of shrimp and chicken.   The squash fritters are as good of a fried appetizer as you're going to get as well, plus they aren't too heavily breaded or greasy so you don't feel too unhealthy eating them.

WrMG2Bo6-v447CBwawwzqQ.text: Despite residing in the Oakland area, I rarely find myself eating here because to be honest, most of the eateries are just not that good or full of drunken undergrads.  However, in a sea of mediocre bars and crappy restaurants, Spice Island is well...and island of deliciousness.  We have been there several times and even thought the restaurant is EXTREMELY small and usually busy, we've always gotten seated and served fairly quickly.  The food is consistently good and their house blend teas are delicious (this is coming from a coffee drinker.)  It's slightly off of the beaten path and as other reviewers have said, the facade is quite ugly, but once you pass through the curtain, you are in for a pleasant surprise.  Give Spice Island a try.  You won't regret it.

G0uconp3pmaWtJw43Kx8YA.text: Don't judge a restaurant by its facade, people!  Spice Island Tea House may look like an unassuming hole-in-the-wall on Atwood, but it serves some quality Thai food.   This is a particularly great place to go for lunch.  They have a large and diverse menu, but I always seem to order my default: the Vegetarian Curry Trio with rice ($8).  It is a delicious mix of eggplant, potato and green beans (the magical trio) and red curry sauce.  A sauce can really make or break a curry and Spice Island's definitely makes it!  It is savory, mildly spicy and very flavorful.  I think my favorite thing about their lunches, though, is that they are the perfect portions!  (Nutrition Nerd Alert!)  Come in hungry and you will feel wonderfully satisfied, but not over-stuffed, and not obligated to take a pile of food home.  The waiters and waitresses are always really chill and courteous.  The ambiance is simple and a tad dark (perfect for a hot summer day!)

Qa58vKb-zde7fXCjUhPmvg.text: Spice Island Tea House is a good restaurant but not amazing. I went on a Wednesday night. Because they're pretty small they can fill up fast. We got there at 6 and by 6:30 every table was taken and had gotten pretty loud. The service was quick and attentive. They were very accommodating.   I can't give this place more than three stars is because I just wasn't impressed by their food. I heard the pad thai was good but it just wasn't that great when I ordered it. The sauce is very sweet with not a lot of depth to it. I thought it could have used more spice or something fresh like green onions or cilantro. Nor was I impressed with their "spicy" laht nah. Its favor was really lacking.  Over Spice Island is good run of the mill thai restaurant with good prices and portions. For vegetarians out there, they are accommodating but almost everything on the menu comes with chicken and shrimp. I would go back if I were in the area but I would definitely order differently.

RaBYJkzO5LNVY_N8vuo9fA.text: I love this place! Penang curry, java fried rice are my fave! I like the tea selections too.

Ao-thhRS7kADf4BkKooVOw.text: I'm a sucker for a heaping, steaming serving of fried rice.  I'm even more of a sucker for spices, both complex and fiery.  Combine the two and you get my favorite dish at Spice Island- a dark brownish fried rice that is rich with spice, bursting with flavor and all around delicious and satisfying.  I've also had one of their curries which was solid, but truly I will return for the fried rice.  Also the decor is charming- sort of tropical Asian inspired.  And their tea menu is surprisingly deep- it's worth digging through if you're into high quality tea.  Delivery is always fun because you get to eat fried rice from a Styrofoam container, which for me brings me back to childhood/college and therefore adds an extra layer of delicious nostalgia.

sIjnBYgwu_NkFpN5_KfJMw.text: I love the interior design! The food is very good too! :) dishes come in large size too:)

KQ8N40uiN-fpdgTFwycn6A.text: This was my favorite restaurant when I lived in Pittsburgh.  Don't judge it by how it looks outside.  It looks shady, but it's far from it.  AMAZING food!!!  I could have eaten here everyday!  My favorite was the Burmese eggplant and shrimp, but I also loved the mango pork and all their curries.  They also have the only coconut ice cream that I ever liked and would more than happily eat again...and they serve it with a fried banana with coconut cream drizzled on top.  I'm drooling just thinking about it!

RZ4CbQzzxiZJvEhRMUPrdA.text: Beef rendang + coconut rice is so good !

igiR4zG5FTu-pk7lAlNPJg.text: This is my absolute favorite restaurant in the city. My favorite is the Thai Basil Fried Rice, but everything I've ordered has been phenomenal. It's an awesome atmosphere- dim lights, relaxed, quiet, calm- and the tea is great. My only gripe is that the tap water tasted like crap every time I've ordered it. All things considered it is a really good, affordable restaurant.

-w_clzqI9bQuZ6Zig1DnVg.text: Spice Island is popular among our hospital crew to order from for lunch in Oakland (via Wheel Deliver).  I have never actually been in the restaurant, so my review will be based strictly on the food.    I have had the pad thai and java fried rice from Spice Island, and both are just OK and forgettable.  The biggest complaint I have with each dish I've had is that the quality of meat and seafood is not very good.  The shrimp in my pad thai was strange tasting and tough and the meat I've had in other dishes was fatty.  Another pet peeve of mine is the amount of grease and oil in the dishes.  I expect a certain amount of oil, but this literally leaves puddles of the stuff at the bottom.  Finally, each dish I've had is disappointingly flavorless.   The portions are HUGE, but I'd rather pay for less food with more flavor.    I have heard great things from friends about Spice Island, so I'd like to actually go to the restaurant to eat some time...but I think I'll be passing for lunch for now on.

n-kJtj-uZK7fa23W8yrDeg.text: I discovered Spice Island through a co-worker about 8 years ago.  As other reviewers have said, the exterior is nondescript and kind of sketchy looking--v. easy to pass right by without noticing what's inside.  But don't let that deter you from going in and sampling some of the best Pan-Asian food in the City.  I like hot tea, and when I saw that Spice Island had a separate menu just for tea (kind of like a wine list at other restaurants), I figured their tea must be pretty good and gave it a try.  And it is.  Over the years I've probably sampled a dozen or so varieties of tea from the menu, and they were all good.  The hot tea is also a wonderful complement to the food, I think.  My favorite appetizer is the shrimp fritters.  It's a good appetizer size, enough for two, served with a tangy vinegary sauce on the side.  Their salads are also very good, too.  It's hard to beat their fried rice dishes.  Cast aside any prior experience or association you may have with fried rice--those soy sauce laden monstrosities that many restaurants pass off as food.  Their fried rice is flavorful, peppered with vegetables, meat, and a bit of heat.  The portions are huge--I have yet to finish an entire portion in one sitting.  So the bonus is a free lunch the next day!  Service is friendly and efficient, even when the place is jumping.  For the amount of food you get and the quality of food, it's one of the best bets in the city.  If you're looking for a fancy place with cloth napkins, beautifully designed interior, this is not it.  Spice Island offers delicious, authentic food served in somewhat humble (but warm and cozy) environment.  In this respect, it reminds me of its restaurant cousin, Tram's in Lawrenceville (great for authentic, inexpensive Vietnamese cuisine).

VrKKEmntEEYeh-uI6laR4Q.text: The food and service was amazing! Some of the best Burmese food in town. I suggest the Lemongrass Beef entree. It was delicious. The space is cute and the staff was friendly. Worth checking out!

JMfS7OhQpwUtAyn0ylLc0A.text: Spice Island Tea House is great. The food is really good and pretty affordable.  There are two daily teas, one hot and one cold, for $1 each, with unlimited free refills. And there's a 5% discount for paying with cash. I'd recommend both! (And the Pad Thai, but that goes without saying.)

New3hbVKBYmqkSeInoCCRA.text: Their service is quick and easy. They have a multitude of tea options, and their Pad Thai is a huge serving- I can never eat it all in one sitting.

CDmV9BX9PdmmCLCuzZDeXg.text: This area is mobbed with college students, the food is cheap and the portion size is huge......those factors Im sure play a major role in some of these 5 star reviews..   We had lunch -  shrimp pad thai and their version of chicken panang. I found the Pad Thai to be sweet and extremely saucy and unfortunately I questioned the 'chicken' that was in my pad thai. Everything on the lunch menu is about 8.50. Personally I've had way better but, I'm not Thai, I've never been to Thailand and the place had a steady flow of ppl so what do I know! Its small and quaint to say the least, dark and unique.  The outside is a lil misguiding but its clean enough and they didn't waste any money on anything, even the menus are cheap, random and possibly homemade - I'd venture to say that nothing there was purchased new. At least this place will be around for a while and the prices have no reason to go up.  Our waiter was nice, and it's not very often that I find places that sell Burmese dishes. Stop by for a try if you're in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

y0braQgyxY5wv_fkN2_nZg.text: This place makes me sad. Why? Because it used to be one of my top 3 favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh. And, if I had written this review 5 years ago, it would have 5 stars for sure. Now, Spice Island has been downgraded to 3 stars. I still go back for the nostalgia of it all. (I did used to eat here once a week.) The food is just not as good anymore. To me it tastes like what used to be good food but now has been mass produced so it's lost a lot of the refined flavors. The sauces used to be awesome, now not so much.   My favorite dishes were/are: pad thai and chicken with string beans. It's still okay, but when you start off outstanding, okay just won't cut it. 3 stars for Spice Island, and mostly just for old time's sake.   Since this is an asian restaurant, and us asians are taught to strive for perfection and settle for nothing less, Spice Island's mom would say "What happened to the other 2 stars?" *  __________________ * Painting a very broad stroke here, when an asian student goes home with a 97 on a test, his or her (or my) mom says, "What happened to the other 3 points?" It's negative reinforcement at it's best.

Ido3FYPpy8TIgz2jIVq-8w.text: The food is pretty good, but why you go is for those menus made out of cardboard that are duct taped together and written on with sharpie. It is just a very unique place.

Eox_EBvdlWJnwTa01L8xjg.text: Consistently excellent and inexpensive food, especially the OL GAHT (eggplant puree), Samoosas, and Lemon Grass Beef.   The Ever-famous Pad Thai and the Green-Lipped Mussels are good but not musts.

Hg68wKiHELftRIHNIbdh9Q.text: This was one of my favorite restaurants as a college student in Pittsburgh.  It's a dingy-looking hole-in-the-wall that's easy to miss from the outside, but the interior is quaint and quirky, the staff is friendly and helpful, and the food is unique.  My go-to entree is the mango pork, and the coconut rice, which comes with most dishes, is addictive.  Keep in mind that the food isn't exactly mind-blowingly delicious, and it's certainly not at all authentic, but it's very tasty and very different compared to your other options within the same area and price-range.  Great place for both small and large groups, too!

vk3I4C6MleZRDD78oINr-w.text: I've been to spice island tea house twice for lunch, and left disappointed both times. For my first meal, I had a broccoli stir fry which can swimming in a non-salty soy sauce concoction. I was happy that it wasn't as salty as it looked, but it wasn't good. The second time I had a tofu curry dish which was much better, but the veggies were over cooked and it lacked the bold flavor that curries should have.

YYuwR-0Cp9niYV3HZiQE7g.text: One of my favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh!!! Definitely a hole in the wall place, but what it lacks in outdoor appearance, it makes up for with its yummy food! Ginger beer cocktails are all wonderful and the tea pots are also amazing. Always get the spring rolls and samoosa appetizers... the sauce that comes with is my favorite. I could bottle it up and drink it! Java fried rice is one of my all time favorites. The pad thai is quite possibly the greatest pad thai I've ever had. Can't say enough good things about this place. It's a go-to for my family and friends and I.

a3XAfbIkgHpddZXRAVdeqg.text: If you dine here, you MUST get the Java Fried Rice. It is the most delicious fried rice I have ever had. I tend to gravitate toward vegetable or noodle dishes at Thai places, but this fried rice is an exception. I have returned for it several times.  Service is great and the atmosphere is quiet. Spice Island is ideal for a quiet dinner with a small group. They serve fairly large takeout portions as well. Prices are very reasonable compared to other Thai places in Pittsburgh.   The Chiang Mai noodles in my opinion were not as good as others I have tried, and the vegetables in garlic sauce were mediocre. The garlic sauce was very good, but the vegetables tasted as though they had been frozen. I do like Spice Islands Pad Thai.   I will still be coming back here often, but I do feel like this place is a bit hit or miss. Highly recommend most of the dishes I have tried here.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chiang Mai Noodles
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Mixed Veggies In Garlic Sauce

YeaQR-TjIi4YIWoprsd55A.text: They have a selection of ginger beer cocktails that will knock your socks off! Bangkok Mule, Dark & Stormy, Gin-Gin Mule, Horse's Neck and several others. Drinks are priced at around $8-$9 which is comparable if not slightly less than other places.  The food is good. I say this about a lot of places but hey, we live in a city with a lot of good places to eat. I think the menu changes now and again because sometimes I will come back and something I have had previously is no longer available. I do love the hearty noodle dishes. They make a coconut chicken noodle soup that is so satisfying and filling.  Burmese chicken curry is full of flavor, juicy and well prepared.  Another nice place to bring friends or family for a decent meal.

iOidmICieYO6nxST2W5fJA.text: Got dinner with some friends spontaneously at 6:30pm on a Saturday and was seated right away! While the place was crowded, our food came out very quickly and it was delicious. I got the Trio Curry and it was wonderfully spiced--and with a little sriracha, it was just the heat I needed for a cold winter day!! I was famished so I finished my entire meal, but my friends were able to box up their food for sizable leftovers.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Trio Curry

yfkFqh60eWVYXQbfYyeTIg.text: Delicious food and reasonable prices! On a Saturday night around 8:30pm we had no trouble getting a table. A friend I was with was excited to see that they served drinks he used to get in Singapore. I stuck with the Thai iced tea, which was on point, just the right amount of sweetness.  To eat I had the "Curry Trio", which was vegetables in a red curry sauce. The flavoring of the curry was wonderful! I also loved how beautifully the food was presented. My friends ordered a variety of chucked dishes, all of which they enjoyed. Our food came out quite fast, which was great considering how hungry we were  I look forward to coming back!

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Curry Trio
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Thai iced tea

Zm8c3lUtWVgcoUnwKli5Cw.text: hole in the wall spot for tasty southeast asian noodles, curries & rice dishes! i've been on many occasions over the years and have always left satisfied. the food is filling, sometimes a bit oily but still delicious.  the java fried rice is my go-to, the perfect balance of sweet and savory, comes in a generous portion and has plenty of protein - both shrimp and chicken! prices are around $10-12 for dinner entrees. portions are large enough that you could split to two meals or eat the whole thing if you're hungry! the pad thai is also one of the better ones I've had in Pittsburgh.  my friends and i easily got a table for 4 at 5:30pm on a tuesday and service was prompt. the space is small and does get busy, so plan accordingly.  don't let the location tucked in the depths of south oakland fool you - spice island's food transports you with the flavors of southeast asia! bonus - 5% discount if you pay cash!

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. java fried rice - generous portions with plenty of chicken and shrimp

nzHaM3jhb-0XOm5UO4RK3w.text: Been here a few times and have never been disappointed. Food is fresh and the menu has a wide variety of dishes. Definitely a unique 'hole in the wall' and prices are reasonable.

7VlafoLw4lVR8olLwvH7Lw.text: This place is so cozy! I've brought so many of my friends here. The portions are pretty big so unless you have a huge stomach you can pretty much have another entire meal for the next day. Even though it's a small location there is usually a table open. Definitely not a good place for big groups, if you have more than 4 people in your party it might be a tight squeeze. A good place for some one on one time. The food is super great. Also the tea is nice.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

OFYGFlNyvAQ4eIYZ8ItyXA.text: Here's the tea (lol). I have dabbled in Thai/Asian fusion but this was out of my bf's comfort zone. The menu is a lil intimidating if you aren't familiar with this food genre. We both got the Thai iced tea loved it. He liked the Pad Thai but he loved my Chiang mai noodles. This place is adventurous, good vibes, and fun food. Hope you're up for a new experience!

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

_RUKpiXUHdej_bbXF9nWsA.text: Very solid and unqiue south asian place in Oakland.  There's lots of Thai food in Pittsburgh, but Spice Island separates itself from the others by offering other styles, namely Burmese and Singaporean, and also having a lengthy tea menu!  Food here is solid all around, which really impresses me, considering how many cuisines they have to serve. My personal favorite is their Singaporean noodles, because of how savory it is. It's fun to pair curries or a mohinga, for example, which has more mellow flavors, with the Singaporean noodles.  The restaurant is also cozy, and very calming honestly for the guests. It's inviting for long conversations and just taking a break here.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Mohinga!
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Burmese chicken curry
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Singaporean noodles

ywQi4Ay7gMWWGGOw-BV_DA.text: Finally got into this place to try it, I had passed it up a couple times because the entrance lacked curb appeal.  But I am happy to say I really liked it and it is much nicer inside than i guessed.    They have a great selection of teams, and a surprisingly good selection of Asian/Thai  style foods, better than I was expecting. I got the beef lemongrass special, my wife got the pad thai. I really liked the beef, the pad thai seems more like it was something that came from a large prepared pot, and I've had better. But it was their lunch special, so I suppose if you order it off the menu it may be better.  I loved the mint/gunpowder tea we had. Tea is.their speciality for sure, I look forward to trying more!

WOrVe0zb2XfYtRDXuel7Tg.text: I have been here twice and the food is very good.  I have had the panaang curry which had a full peanut flavor.. could be overwhelming for some.  The second time i had Spicy Chili Fried Rice with Mixed Seafood... it was good as well.  Lots of seafood and lots of flavors. My daughter loves the java fried rice and has gotten it on both visits.  I will keep coming back.   So before I posted this review I was in Oakland and came back. I had the Bermese pork curry with a side of coconut rice. This was from the lunch menu.  I had it with Thai coffee.  My daughters had Java fried rice (of course) with Thai tea and my sister pad Thai.   While the bermese curry was very flavorful it wasn't like a typical curry. The pork was very tender and it had potatoes as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegetable spring rolls
Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Gunpowder green tea

26-u5V8rO38IfhVKm8_vYA.text: If you're looking for a one-stop-shop for southern Asian cuisine, Spice Island is it. They have a little bit of everything. Whether it's Burmese, Thai, or Malaysian and that's just naming three of the cuisines they offer.   I've been here a couple times and each time, I leave wanting to come back because the menu has so much that I want to try from different cuisines. The first time, we ordered Chang Mai and Singapore rice noodles. The second time, we ordered the Malaysian Beef Rendang and Shan Tribe Hot and Sour Noodle Soup. Both times, we got samosas as our appetizer, which you can't go wrong with. I've enjoyed everything we've gotten here, including their creative cocktails. My favorite cocktails are the ones with their homemade ginger beer.  I definitely plan on revisiting Spice Island again and again. The space is intimate, making it a great setting for delicious southern Asian food.

e6p5thGLCp7zVZN9xA589w.text: The taste is okay but there are some other better Thai food out of Oakland.

smb5zOKd1Z-RgcDuCH8jQw.text: Ummm..... ugh. Such a disappointment.  Either it has gone downhill since college or maybe my palette has changed, but Spice Island SUCKs.  There are so many better places in Pittsburgh to eat.  I will never return.  We started with the soup of the day and a salad.  Both were ok, nothing special.  My partner ordered the Java rice and I ordered the Panang Curry.  The rice was ok.  The curry was disgusting.  Quite possibly the worst I have ever had.  It was too thick, like old gravy thick and had no flavor.  Literally no spice.  Embarrassingly bad.  The service our entire time there was nonexistent.  We had to flag someone down the entire time, had to re-explain simple requests like asking for straws multiple times and waited for our check for 15 awkward minutes.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Gross thick panang curry, disgusting.

tzhDXQ5gbcqJu30aAZVzAg.text: OVERALL: my favorite Southeast Asian restaurant in Oakland. Delicious curries, warm and sweet coconut rice, and life-changing roti canai. The cons are that there is usually a long wait if you come during prime hours, and they don't have many vegetables in their curry entrees.  I'll start off by saying that I regret not eating at Spice Island sooner. Since discovering it three months ago, I've been there a total of about 6 or 7 times and definitely plan on going again. The food here is really phenomenal, flavorful, and always served hot.   My favorite dishes are the burmese pork curry, lemongrass beef curry, java fried rice, and roti canai. Seriously, if you come here, you have to order the roti canai! Every single time I've eaten here, no matter how stuffed I know I will become from the entree, I order roti canai - and I never regret it, despite my bloating stomach complaining afterward. However, the one dish I did not enjoy was the Chicken Malaysian Sate on skewers. I wasn't a fan of the peanut sauce, and the chicken seemed lackluster in terms of flavor and presentation.  One complaint I have about the food is that it is a bit too salty, and it could use some more vegetables. Whenever I order curry, the only vegetables it comes with are potatoes...which is terrific, because I love potatoes, but I do wish there were more greens and healthy vegetables in the dish. Also, the wait can get long due to the large amount of customers during peak hours. If you come, try and come before 11:30am or after 3pm for lunch, and before 6pm for dinner!

odEhcfWEdDhwU7iiecTHrQ.text: Tea is always fantastic and every food item I have eaten (usually the special of the day) has been flavorful and comforting.

photos.caption: Photo of Spice Island Tea House - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Spice Island Tea House

YQ4Nta4tzfhvXC5U4iO3JQ.text: This was a place that I frequented for several years throughout undergrad. I absolutely love this place - it's a very "hole in the wall" type of restaurant that's tucked away on Atwood.   To be quite honest, I only order the Java Fried Rice here. The menu has changed quite a bit since I first started coming here but they thankfully kept the java fried rice. It is by far the best dish and I think it's worth it to visit here just for that dish.

S0BfDdjqNQgUOypeFmtViw.text: My new go to asian food. I got the malaysian beef rendang with coconut rice. The beef rendang is spiced well and very tender. The coconut rice is umami without any saltiness which makes it go really well with the savory beef rendang. If you like spicy, their chili oil goes really well with it. Additionally, the waitress is very nice and attentive.

8B_4jd4-m7vLx3LKNDim9w.text: Love this little hidden gem in south Oakland! Very affordable and great large portions! The food is delicious and there are a lot of vegetarian options too! Highly recommend their curries, pad Thai, and fried rice!

4NJ2aQLN66trYULdOvx0HA.text: $12 bucks just for rice...  The Basil fried rice with shrimp is da bomb. But this place is just too expensive.  The rice was about $10 and I came here occasionally because that's pretty steep for a college-town bowl of rice. About a month ago, they raised all of their menu prices. I couldn't believe it. Now, it's about $12 bucks for some rice! Good but way too overpriced.   They should add a chicken basil rice option and make it cheaper - I may come back.

ID9JNYOJjyeKY4PlkqTucg.text: Friendly staff, generous portions, incredible food.

fwtXD_zad018-Sy4B6T4yA.text: I ordered the crab rolls, the Hot and Sour Soup, and shrimp in red basil curry.  I enjoyed every item that I had and thought each was better than average.  I especially like the rolls and soup.  All in all, a great meal.  I hope to get to this place more often.

ozPu0KZTsuuBCBSyBNVEWA.text: This is a favorite restaurant of mine, and I've been here many times. I always like trying new things on the menu, but my absolute favorite dish is the Mango Pork/Burmese Pork (they changed the same). Slow cooked pork in a dark, flavorful sauce and coconut rice, it's just fantastic. The Night Market Noodles, the Pad Thai and the Java Fried Rice are all also excellent.

lQx5aAT-2QV7Bvy-C0KezQ.text: Yummy tofu! Some of the best tofu I've ever had in the Penang Curry dish :) My bf wasn't impressed with his meal though, which made me sad. It was Burmese Pork Curry but he said wasn't that tasty. I couldn't taste cause I only eat veggies. I would definitely return though!!

9DzdqrX5bA2-8QKE150KWA.text: Good: It's a romantic spot, byob, best pad thai in the city, nice wait staff Bad: it's rather small, the vegetable to noodle ratio is kind of lacking

Qr2DzcyKlA4EmWhuJs1ZgA.text: We had the Pad Thai w/ shrimp & chicken; possibly the tastiest thing I ever ate in my life!

w-NdYFelmUjmxool8trqjg.text: This place is awesome. I've been twice now, once for lunch and once for dinner, and each time was great. The prices are low and the servings are huge. I really recommend the chicken pad Thai and the java fried rice. If you go for lunch, the portions are enormous so you don't need an appetizer or anything. Definitely will be back many times!
